page.title: 08Language and it's origins
page.content: The area around the villages of Great and Little Raveley and Wistow border on the edge of the fens and the English spoken has an East Anglian dialect, originated from Anglo Saxon with variations provided by the Danes and the Flemish. Phrases sometimes heard are 'I've never been so fite in all me life' and one can often be referred to as 'me duck'. The use of 'bootiful' instead of beautiful is very common. 'Newcomers' from London have introduced Cockney dialects and encouraged the dropping of the 'H'. There is also a high proportion of middle class families and the Royal Air Force resulting in the use of the 'Queen's English'. American Air Force Personnel in the area have added their own flavour to the language. The area has, therefore, an interesting mix of the best and worst of our language.
